description.narrative: The project aims to support the parliament in the four main areas of its constitutional responsibility: lawmaking, setting policy direction, executive oversight, and representation.

title.narrative: 00057935 Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia 2014-2016 EU
00057935 Strong Parliament in a Consolidated Democracy 20102013 NETH

description.narrative: Increased Functionality of the Parliament.
Elections - elections

1. Availability of Parliament's Institutional Reform Plan (IRP). 2. New mandate for the Parliament's international relations services. 3. Citizen-oriented public outreach activities. Number of Parliament's commitments in Open Government Partnership (OGP). 4. Number of amendments to parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP), including alignment with the latest constitutional changes. 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination system in place and operational. 6. Number of committee action plans in place and operational. 7. Number of staff trainings on legislative and financial monitoring functions (summoning committee meetings, conducting government hearings, organizing public sessions, scrutinizing program budgets, utilizing budget execution and State Audit reports, etc.) 8. Action plan and communications roadmap of Committee on European integration in place and operational. Number of staff trainings on legal harmonization and overall integration issues; knowledge-sharing activities (study visits, conferences) with EU Member States. 9. Number of public outreach activities (Europe Day celebration, media workshops, etc.) on European integration processes.

comment.narrative: 1. The Parliament of Georgia lacks a vision of its development strategy. 2. Insufficient structured approach to international relations. Respective parliamentary services perform only protocol functions. 3. The Parliament's public trust is not sufficient. It lacks transparency and adequate public outreach. 4. Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are not realigned with the latest constitutional amendments. 5. Donor coordination in the Parliament remains ineffective. 6. Parliamentary committees lack strategic approach to exercising their constitutional functions. 7. Law-making and oversight capacities of parliamentary committees remain weak. 8. There is a cross-party consensus in favour of Georgia's accelerated European integration; however, both Members and staff of the Parliament lack sufficient knowledge of European issues. 9. There is a low public awareness on Georgia-European Union relations, where the Parliament has a decisive role to play.

1. Institutional Reform Plan finalized and adopted by the Parliament. 2. Concept on International relations agreed with the Parliament; respective amendments to the parliamentary regulations made. 3. Communications strategy developed. Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan developed. 4. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) initiated 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. 7. Parliamentary staff , including from targeted sector committees have greater capacities for fulfilling their duties 8. Action plan of the Committee on European Integration (CEI), communications roadmap and capacity development plan finalized. .

comment.narrative: With regard to the enabling legal and institutional environment for PA financing, in the recent years the Government has created a number of legal and institutional prerequisites for increasing the financial sustainability of the PA system.

description.narrative: To secure long-term financial sustainability of the Georgian PA system
Area of sustainably financed PAs

comment.narrative: At least 100,000 ha cat. I-II by 2013 400,000 ha cat. I-IV by 2017. This target was re-formulated following MTR as agreed by PEB.
286,458.36 ha category I-IV

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative:
0.47
The baseline level was 0.34 excluding the assumed increase in funding from revenues generated by the sister project (see below).

0.625
The ratio of current financing to optimally required financing reached 0.58 at year-end 2013 according to Financial Scorecard at mid-term review. This figure takes the total revenues available to PAs and divides it by the optimal funding calculation at 2013. Following MTR, the PEB agreed to adjust this target downwards from the original 0.7 for two reasons. First, the optimal funding foreseen in the Financial Scorecard increased compared to project outset, which made it even more challenging to achieve the planned financing level. A more fundamental reason to reduce the target, however, was that all assumed incremental funding sources are falling somewhat short of their planned additions to system revenues as described below. The Project Documents (Annex G) assumed an improvement of $1.114 million from the tourism and concession revenues generated as a result of the sister project. 2013 revenues from tourism and concessions amounted to almost $650,000. While not all tourism and concession revenues are actually attributable to the sister project, for purposes of these calculations they are all attributed to the sister project. Nevertheless, it seems unlikely that tourism revenues will increase by the planned amount by 2017. An improvement of $1.019 million was assumed from State funding. So far, while there has been a GEL increase in the budget, no dollar increase has been achieved (the GEL exchange rate weakened from $1.4/GEL in 2008 to $1.68/GEL in 2013). The 2008 baseline was $2.9 million in State funding for the PAs--the same amount as is shown in 2013. Finally, CNF's own target at present is to reach $800,000 per annum by 2017, an increase of $300,000 from 2013, but still $150,000 short of the planned $950,000 annual contribution assumed from CNF in the project document. If CNF funding can reach $800,000 and tourism revenues or the state budget can increase by $200,000, the revised 0.625 target can be achieved.

A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio will be completed for the TE in 2017.
$612,000 disbursed by CNF in 2014, as such established annual target was factually reached.
During 2015, CNF plans to disburse $ 567,095. As of June 30, 2015, CNF factually disbursed up to $ 286,500, on track to meet the 2015 target. Expressed in Euro, CNFs main currency, CNF support to PAs increases annually, but due to the devaluation of the Euro against the $, the target for 2015 appears lower than planned.
Government funding in 2014 increased in GEL by 31.8% compared to 2013, due to major investments in infrastructure

description.narrative: Critical ecosystems of protected areas providing habitats for endemic and endangered species are conserved

comment.narrative: Ecosytems are deteriorating
Habitats in 4-5 Cat I-II PAs are conserved by 2013

CNF currently supports 9 Cat I-IV PAs, including for better accountancy, planning, and patrolling.
Data collected for 4 species as part of the established pilot biodiversity monitoring program in BKNP during 2014 are being analyzed.
A replication biodiversity monitoring program is designed for implementation in Lagodekhi PA during 2015.

description.narrative: Ensuring sufficiency and predictability of revenue sources for the PA system
Reduce annual funding gap by $440,000 by 2013

comment.narrative:
70% of basic funding
The baseline level in 2008 was actually 51%. 70% is the 2013 target with the sister project. The 2013 target is 88% including the projected increase in government funding. CNF was to add $440,000 to this increased 2013 financing level.
47% of optimal funding
See the comments above. This includes the projected revenues from the sister project.

94% of basic funding
Under the assumptions on the reduction of project targets discussed above (CNF adds $800,000 by project end and an additional $200,000 are provided by a combination of increased government and tourism related funding), following MTR the PEB adjusted this target is from 96% to 94% of basic funding (and 62.5% of optimal funding).

Financial scorecard at MTR assessed combined support from government and donors to cover 86% of basic funding, or 58% of optimal funding.
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap with $612,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 567,095.
CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of $ 800,000 by project end (revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR).

description.narrative: US$ value of capitalization of sinking fund.

comment.narrative: Technically speaking, the value of the GEF Sinking Fund (SFAF1) is still $1,000,000, since no additional donations to this particular sinking fund were made. Meanwhile CNF has received significant donations outside the sinking fund. To give a sense of the reality of the project, CNF reports $4,554,000 (taking into account GEF funding plus 1/3 of Euro 12 million funding from BMZ plus private donations). We are therefore significantly above the target of $2,435,000. To December 2014 we spent $2 million in the PAs and plan a further $567,095 in 2015, reaching our spending target of $2,435,000. In addition to this funding we have received a further EUR 5 million into the endowment, putting us on target for a long term funding capacity of $800,000 pa.

description.narrative: Number of PAs financed from CNF

comment.narrative: CNF is currently not financing any PAs
Four to five PAs financed by 2013

In 2015, 9 PAs are receiving support from CNF: 6 PAs receive full operational support (BKNP, LPA, VPA, TPA, MNP and JPA), while 3 PAs (Kazbegi, Kintrishi and Algeti) are receiving planning and infrastructure funding from KfW and "basic" operational support-- salaries top-up and some smaller items--from CNF.

description.narrative: Increase in tools PA system revenue generation

comment.narrative: An agreement in principle has been reached with the MoENRP for the relevance of introducing PA entry fees. High level staff changes have hampered making further progress.

description.narrative: Long-term annual funding capacity of CNF available for Georgia based on its endowment, sinking fund and other regular annual commitments.

comment.narrative:
$950,000 (original target)
$800,000 (revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR)

CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of $ 800,000 by project end.
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap with $612,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 567,095.

description.narrative: Raising cost-effectiveness and capacities of PAs

Increase in cost-effectiveness of at least 10 PAs measured by financial score card (part II, component II);
The discussion at MTR indicate that the FSSC is not feasible at PAs level and cannot be used to assess the cost-efficiency of PAs. The MTR suggested that this indicator be replaced by the following: \\\"An accounting system is in place at APA and adopted that covers all PAs\\\"

comment.narrative:
0.08
Only a very basic accounting system exists.

0.33
A modern and fully functional accounting system is in place (original indicator)
An accounting system is in place at APA and covers all PAs (as revised by PEB after the MTR).
An accounting system (hardware and software) has been established at APA and covers all PAs. During the transitional year 2015, APA will upload balance sheet data.

description.narrative:
Adoption of site specific business plans at 10 PAs providing transparency on the optimum level of management costs
The MTR recommended that this indicator be replaced by the following: \\\"Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the PAs covered by CNFâ€?

comment.narrative:
10 business plans adopted 10 PAs (original target)
Technical assistance has been provided and Operational Plans are in effect at all PAs covered by CNF (8-9 PAs) in 2016 (as revised by the PEB after the MTR).
Operational plans (OPs) were developed and submitted by BKNP, VPA and TPA. In 2015, additionally OPs were prepared for JPA, Kazbegi, Algeti and Kintrishi PAs.

description.narrative: Number of site managers trained in cost-effective management

comment.narrative:
At least three in a minimum of 10 targeted PAs (original target)
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs (target revised by the PEB after the MTR).

Training in the use of the accounting system has been provided to 9 members of APA’s central staff and PA staff in 2014.
Additional training is planned for 2015 to staff of newly CNF-supported PAs.

description.narrative: Existence of electronic system to track changes in management effectiveness based on the METT score and - where appropriate - on the Financial Sustainability Scorecard.

comment.narrative: No such system exists
Development and implementation of such a system

In 2014, an updated METT Scorecard was prepared for LPA, in conjunction to a renewed grant agreement. For JPA the baseline METT Scorecard was prepared.
In 2015, updated METT Scorecards for renewed grant agreement will be prepared for TPA and VPA. Baseline METT Scorecards will be prepared for Kazbegi, Algeti and Kintrishi PAs.

comment.narrative: To improve resilience of highly exposed regions of Georgia to hydro-meteorological threats that are increasing in frequency and intensity as a result of climate change

description.narrative: Governance Reform Fund (GRF) project serves the overall objective of further strengthening capacities of the Government of Georgia and increasing its effectiveness and efficiency.

The CDF mechanism of the GRF project provides support to sub-project initiatives that strengthen the capacity of the Government for the implementation of public sector reforms through contributing to transformational change of supported institutions.

comment.narrative: Georgia has made considerable progress in making its public administration system more effective, efficient, transparent, and citizen-friendly. International partners and donors have supported the Government of Georgia in these efforts. However, challenges persist in the consistent implementation of evidence-based decision making, policy formulation, long-term strategy development, as well as the retention of institutional capacity. In addition, comprehensive internal reforms and the requirements of implementing the Association Agreement/ DCFTA signed with the EU increase transformational pressures on the system.
1. Number of projects under CDF launched
1. One sub-project "Promoting Capacity Building of the State Agencies involved in the Waste" launched

comment.narrative: Preliminary co-financing agreements made
Investors closed financing as per pilot plant's business plan

10%
Feasibility study was conducted for Tbilisi that revealed that it is not most appropriate location for investing . Thus, the Board decided to consider regional coverage and in this regards the competition that will help to identify production and utilization partners is now in process. Since Georgian Regions are considered as main target for the production and utilization, country wide business plan competition is in process of preparation. Competition will reveal partners.

description.narrative: Shida Kartli Integrated Socio-Economic Development
The programme assists the displaced and host communities in the Shida Kartli region through promoting small-scale farming and raising household income of farming families.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

1.1/ # of farmers received consultations and services of extension center 1.2/ # of innovations disseminated and applied by means of Extension Service provider. 1.3/ # of farmers trained in agri-business skills 1.4/ accessibility of green house for demonstration sessions and accessibility of seedlings for local farmers 1.5/ Accessibility of practical and theoretical knowledge, appropriate inventory and facility for local farmers 2.1/ availability of results of market survey 2.2/ availability of fruit dryer 2.3/ # of local farmers using fruit druer 2.4/ # of demonstration sessions provided at Gori University Dairy Plant. 3.1/ availability of market information on off season fresh products 3.2/ links established between fresh fruit buyers and famers 3.3/ availability of new cold storage facilities. 5.1/ # of inputs delivered and # of demonstration plots arranged 6.1/ # kindergarten building rehabilitated, renovated and operational 6.2/ # of water systems installed and operational 9.1/ Economic Baseline Survey conducted.

comment.narrative: 1.1/ No regular and institutionalized extension services accessible to all vulnerable communities; 1.2/ No facilities and formats for initiation of innovative methods in farming are available in the area. 1.3/ No agri-business training provided to farmers 1.4/No enough green houses operate in the region serving for demonstration needs and providing local farmers with seedlings 1.5/ No enough beekeeping farms operates and no trainings and education provided in this field in the region 2.1/ No high quality market information on dried fruits 2.2/No template design of simple fruit dryer available for farmers 2.3/ Lack of fruit drying facilities available for local farmers 2.4/ Lack of practical demonstration possibilities available for local farmers in processing 3.1/ Lack of market information on market for fresh off season products. 3.2/ No regular links between fresh fruit buyers and farmers. 3.4 / Lack of availability of cold storages. 5.1/ Lack of agriculture facilities and inputs in the area 6.1/ No modern and unsafe kindergarten existing 6.2/ No drinking water system existing in the selected area 9.1/ In 2014 UNHCR conducted “Participatory Assessment for Identification of Integration Needs of Refugees and Humanitarian Status Holders in Georgia”, which revealed several problems regarding livelihoods, housing, education and health. Economic Baseline Survey is required to better inform the Process of planning of their protection and integration/

7.1/Needs assessment for technical assistance to Information Consultation Centers conducted and relevant technical assistance provided to at least 2 Information Consultancy Centers in Shida Kartli municipalities 7.2.1/ Livelihood needs assessment of farmers of selected areas conducted to reveal most demanded vocations in the region. 7.2.2/ At least 50 farmers trained with quality vocational trainings in the most demanded agricultural vocations 8.1/ At least 270 farmers in Shida Kartli municipalities provided with farming (inputs and relevant advises (trainings) for further activity) 8.2/ At least 20 farms’ infrastructure upgraded 8.3/ At least 4 farmers cooperatives established and or supported comprised of target community members 9.1/ In 2014 UNHCR conducted “Participatory Assessment for Identification of Integration Needs of Refugees and Humanitarian Status Holders in Georgia”, which revealed several problems regarding livelihoods, housing, education and health. Economic Baseline Survey is required to better inform the Process of planning of their protection and integration/ Economic Baseline Survey conducted.

description.narrative: Fostering Local and Regional Development

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

title.narrative: Mid term evaluation for the project: Fostering Regional and Local Development in Georgia

description.narrative: The project aims to advance decentralization, regional and local governance reform and development through strengthening capacities of central and sub-national authorities.
capital of a political entity
Accountability - local government finance

1.1. No. of essential policy reforms developed and led by MRDI in an inclusive and participatory manner 1.2. MRDI providing effective inter-ministerial coordination and support to the regions and municipalities in developing, implementing and monitoring the development plans; 1.3. No. of legal acts related to the regional and local governance reform and development adopted and improved in a participatory manner, based on wide consultations 1.4. Extent of substantive involvement of the Parliamentary Committees in the relevant reforms 1.5. Effective thematic coordination process on regional/local development established 1.6. Total no. of direct beneficiaries 2.1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated)1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated) 2.2 No. of Regional Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner in project regions; 2.3. No. of Municipal Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner and reflected in the programme budgets 2.4. Adequate participation of women and men in the regional development and municipal planning and implementation ensured

comment.narrative: 1. MRDI is in process of designing policy reforms, but none completed so far; Regional Development Commission established but yet to become fully operational; MRDI to enhance its guidance to regions and municipalities; The upcoming reforms of the LSG system require revisions to the key laws and legal acts; Insufficient policy making and capacities of Parliamentary Committees in relevant subject; MRDI has yet to develop system of donor coordination at policy and thematic levels. 2. No beneficiaries of the project output so far; No RDPs available; No LSG has an up-to date MDP; about 10 LSGs have prior experience in working on MDPs, or an outdated MDP. Hence, no LSG have programme budgets reflecting MDP priorities; Women, generally take less than 20% places in discussions and decision-making (11% in Sakrebulos). 3. GOG decree #1182/2012 establishing the basis for training of MRDI, Governor’s and LSG civil servants; GOG has allocated no budgetary resources for training LSG officials; No systemic and state coordinated trainings organized for LSGs .

1.1 At least 300 person/days of training organized to improve staff capacities in 11 key areas-identified from functional analyses 1.2 At least 3 key policy areas and resources fully decentralized to local government, including : central competencies • staff management and incentivisation • local development policy and project development • monitoring and accounting for resources spent on participatory local and regional development 1.3 By 2015 at least 4 sectoral and cross-sectoral policy debates and legislative discussions facilitated by the Parliamentary Committee on RPSG; At least 10 draft laws related to the regional and local governance reform/ development initiated/moved to the parliamentary readings by the Parliamentary Committees 1.4 By 2015 the national legislation essentially in line with the European charter of local self-governance more than 30 legal acts related to the regional and local governance reform and development adopted and improved 1.5 By 2015 LSG primary competencies widened; By 2015 municipal budgets (excluding Tbilisi) make at least 12% of consolidated budget
2.1 At least 6 regions and at least 20 municipalities have pro-poor development strategies developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner (with participation of at least 40% of women) and resourced 2.2 At least 3 actions from RDPs and at least 10 actions from MDPs implemented; At least 75% of these actions are gender sensitive 2.3 At least 40,000 inhabitants are benefited from the development projects and improved services; At least 40% of beneficiaries are female 2.4 At least 10 municipalities adopting programme budgets in line with the MDPs 2.5 At least 12% of women are elected in local Sakrebulos (up from 10.5%)

Hence, no LSG have programme budgets reflecting MDP priorities 2.4: Women, generally take less than 20 % places in discussions and decision-making (11 % in sakrebulos) 3.1: GOG decree #1182/2012 establishing the basis for training of MRDI, Governor’s and LSG civil servants. 3.2: GOG has allocated no budgetary resources for training LSG officials (2011) 3.3: No systemic and state coordinated trainings organized for LSGs (2011)

2.1 At least 6 regions and at least 20 municipalities have pro-poor development strategies developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner (with participation of at least 40% of women) and resourced 2.2 At least 3 actions from RDPs and at least 10 actions from MDPs implemented; At least 75% of these actions are gender sensitive 2.3 At least 40,000 inhabitants are benefited from the development projects and improved services; At least 40% of beneficiaries are female 2.4 At least 10 municipalities adopting programme budgets in line with the MDPs 2.5 At least 12% of women are elected in local Sakrebulos (up from 10.5%)

description.narrative: The overall objective of this phase (2014-2015) is to contribute to incorporating/formalising the VET re-training system into the formal VET system as an additional impetus for improving employability of the labour force.
policy, planning and administration

1/ The Concept for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational Education and Training (VET) system and tested in selected two colleges. 2/ Conceptual vision for application of software and other teaching methodologies in VET and its piloting in selected two colleges 3/ A conceptual vision and plan is developed for application of internal QI systems and their testing in selected colleges 4/ The methodology for employment programmes design and national institutional set-up design for their implementation is available

comment.narrative: 1/ No concept exist for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational and Education Training (VET) system 2/ No vision and feasible plan for application of soft and other digital teaching technologies in VET 3/ No conceptual vision and feasible plan for improving under-developed internal quality management system in VET colleges 4/ No Employment Supporting Programmes design methodology and national institutional set-up for implementing demand driven employment supporting programmes exist

1/ Piloting of vocational retraining schemes in selected two colleges (for at least 100 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women). 2/ Testing and piloting new software application in two selected colleges. 3/ The conceptual vision and plan for application of internal Quality Management (QM) systems is developed and QM systems application is supported in selected two colleges. 4/ Newly developed programmes are piloted and their impact is assessed in selected colleges (for at least 110 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women).

1/ Vocational retraining schemes are being piloted in two colleges (Iberia - Kuutaisi and Phazisi - Poti). Nearly 50 students applied out of which 8% is women 2/ Trainings of teachers are undergoing for application of the new software in colleges. 3/ The internal Quality Management (QM) systems application recommendations are developed. QM systems are applied in two colleges (Iberia and Phazisi). 4/ Newly developed Vocational Training programs linked to employment scheme is undergoing (for 50 students out of which 8% women). description.narrative: Confidence Building Early Response Mechanism (COBERM) - Phase 2
Confidence Building Early Response Mechanism (COBERM) - Phase 2
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.1/ Number of people and communities having direct interaction across conflict divides 2.1/ Changed perceptions and attitudes measured through public surveys/opinion polls 2.2/ Number and type of issues/conflict triggers identified and resolved through dialogue/peaceful means 2.3/ Improved access to services (through infrastructure development initiatives), which have a demonstrable positive 'spill over' effect near the ABL. 3.1/Community capacities particularly the role of women in non -violent conflict resolution increased Indicator 3.2 3.2/ Civil Society and Government contacts; engagement of the civil society and media in decision making process and its capacity to hold authorities accountable through peaceful and constructive means increased.

comment.narrative: 1.1/ Rapid response mechanism was established to support confidence building opportunities which seek to prevent and transform conflicts in Georgia. However, the existing mechanism still has to facilitate such a response and continue its assistance in translating the ideas from the grassroots into immediate actions. 2.1/ Myths and prejudices prevail, perceptions across community divides manifested in a lack of trust/confidence, limited cross-community interaction and persisting risk of violence. 2.2/ Polarized opinions vis-à-vis process for reconciliation; Physical and invisible divides hinder dialogue and prevent peaceful transformation/prevention of conflicts. Violent resolution of disputes remains a high risk. 3.1/ A high proportion of community members, particularly women, declare not having access to confidence building mechanisms. However, women are actively representing their communities in confidence building activities implemented in the field. 3.2/ Limited capacity of national NGOs to mediate local level conflict. Persisting lack of professionalism of the media in providing balanced, factually accurate and contextually authentic information while covering crisis situations.

Targets for 2015: 1.1/ At least 20,000 people in 20 communities having direct interaction across conflict areas through grassroots opportunities identified and sub-projects designed/implemented to support direct people-to-people contacts or enhance an enabling environment within the divided communities; 2.1/ At least 10 issues/conflict triggers identified and resolved through dialogue peaceful means. 2.2/ Improved access to services (through infrastructure development initiatives), which have a demonstrable positive “spillover” effect near the ABL (at least 5 initiatives). 3.1.2/ Empowered women and youth (at least 40%) playing increasing role in peaceful transformation of conflicts. 3.2/ At least one civil society network formed or strengthened; Capacity of at least 25 national NGOs to mediate local level conflict and hold authorities accountable through peaceful and constructive means improved means improved. 3.3/ Professionalism of at least 2 media companies in providing balanced, factually accurate and contextually authentic information while covering crisis situations enhanced.

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to support the RC and UNDP to lead international efforts in Georgia on conflict prevention, post-conflict recovery, and peace and development initiatives.
Support to the RC and UNDP to lead international efforts in Georgia on conflict prevention, post-conflict recovery, and peace and development initiatives.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicators 1: 1.1 # of analyses, reports, briefings, etc provided to RR/RC, UNDP, UNCT, HQ elements 1.2 # of PDA consultations/contributions to the development and implementation of UNDP-led conflict transformation and/or peacebuilding activities 1.3 establishing closer strategic coordination & conflict sensitivity mainstreaming in programs 1.4 # contributions and/or events to developing ECIS-wide PDA COP and greater coherence. Indicators 2: 2.1.1 a Common Framework is endorsed by AWG members, and then presented to key partners including the Georgian Government, de facto authorities and Geneva co-Chairs 2.1.2 # of strategic level coordination meetings, both at technical and Ambassadorial level 2.2 # of technical level working meetings that unite international operational & strategic actors # of high-level events in support of process
Indicator 3: 3.1 # weekly analytical reports generated by ELVA ; # tracking reports generated by ELVA; 3.2 # of new projects launched to engage communities on both sides and across conflict divides 3.3 # of CSO peace-building initiatives supported

comment.narrative:
Baseline 1: 1.1 regular analysis, advisory and reporting mechanism established within the RC Office 1.2 synergies exist between various UNDP/UNCT programmatic activities in/on Abkhazia and South Ossetia, but lack holistic approach and strategic coordination across all activities 1.3 Low strategic connectivity with local and international NGOs engaged in peace-building activities in/with Abkhazia and South Ossetia 1.4 regional (ECIS) COP to facilitate exchanges, lessons learnt, best practices, etc small, irregular Baseline 2: operational activities periodically disrupted by political events and subject to political pressure
2.1.1 participatory conflict analysis completed and a strategic Common Framework adopted by Tbilisi-based Ambassadors 2.1.2 lack of strategic level coordination on conflict transformation and peacebuilding efforts among key bilateral donors and international partners 2.2 little synergy between international operational (humanitarian and development ) and strategic (political) approaches to dealing with conflicts Baseline 3: 3.1 community security network established, with regular reporting/analysis generated but minimal connectivity to security providers, and no contact with counterparts across the ABL 3.2 minimal cross-conflict divide connectivity, due to political restrictions, and lack of will to engage/cooperate by communities on both sides 3.3 CSO peacebuilding activities sporadic and have minimal impact on wider context or society

Target 1 1.1 Activity: Continuous political analysis and advice of political developments, democratic process and conflict-related issues at domestic and geopolitical level. 1.2 Activity: Explore opportunities for wider UN dialogue with the Government of Georgia (GoG) on a peace and development strategy, including direct engagement in/on Abkhazia and South Ossetia (including offering proposals/solutions based on UN international expertise and experience, for example, on Georgian-Abkhaz trans-Inguri trade relations, UN senior mediation support (MSU) for an inclusive political/GoG dialogue platform on developing and elaborating GoG peace and development strategy, etc.); 1.3 Activity: Support to RC, UNCT and DPA in preparation of a visit of USG Feltman to Georgia, including key UN political messages on conflict and peacebuilding issues for GoG (tentative - to be confirmed); 1.4 Activity: Exchange visits by PDAs Georgia-Ukraine to facilitate knowledge sharing, including visits to conflict areas – including joint UN policy paper with comparative study of Georgia-Ukraine conflict contexts and lessons learned (one week exchange visit for peer-to-peer PDA learning)
Target 2 2.1 Activity: Support to RC and periodic joint UN-led analysis/coordination meetings (Abkhazia Strategic Partnership; Joint Consultative Forum; Humanitarian Coordination Group; Abkhazia Working Group) 2.2 Activity: Provide strategic guidance and technical support to RC/UNCT in preparation for, and participation, in Geneva International Discussions (GID); PDA liaison between UNCT and other UNRGID/PDA on GID related issues, coordination and information sharing, including development of UN strategy for GID.
Target 3 3.1 Activity: Planning and implementation of a joint needs assessment to assess humanitarian, recovery and development needs/gaps in Abkhazia and 3W project mapping in cooperation with UNCT/APS/ OCHA as basis for evidence-based programming. 3.2 Activity: Development and provision

description.narrative: Sustainable Management of Pastures in Georgia to Demonstrate Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Benefits and Dividends for Local Communities

Rehabilitate 4,064 ha of degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas, introduce methods for migratory route rehabilitation applied in a 300 ha area and introduce/implement sustainable pasture management practices in the Dedoplistskaro region.
capital of a political entity

1) Sustainable pasture management plan developed and implemented 2) 300 ha migratory routes rehabilitated; 3) Local farmers knowledge in sustainable land management practices increased and SLM practices applied. 4) Pilot projects established and lessons learned extracted and disseminated. 5) Capacity of Association of sheep-breeders is improved to coordinate the activities. 6) Carbon release and sequestration monitoring established and conducted. 7) Inter-ministerial policy debate on pastures management issues initiated on national level. Key priority actions agreed. 8) Rehabilitation of 4 064 ha of degraded land. 9) Introduction of sustainable land use practices. 10) Monitoring system on climate conditions introduced 11) Introduction of new technologies. 12) Increase in productivity in piloted areas.

Official demarcation of PA boundaries in progress.

description.narrative: PA System Expanded to increase functional connectivity of PAs in the West Lesser Caucasus
Extent (ha) of area surveyed, and formally proclaimed and managed as Machakhela National Park (IUCN Cat II)

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Machakhela National Park covering 8,733 ha by yr 2

PA official gazettement completed - The Government of Georgia undertook efforts at the project development stage to legally establish the Machakhela NP. This was agreed by Parliament in April 2012. Detailed boundary demarcation is currently in progress with the support of the project. NP Administration has been established and equipped by the Agency of Protected Areas of Georgia . Project has supported initial training of NP Administration staff, awareness raising within local communities, and establishment of the NP administration, local authorities and project coordination group, as well as refurbishment of NP temporary office within the Machakhela valley.

description.narrative: Distance between the Mtirala/Kintrishi PA Complex and the nearest Forest Habitat PA

comment.narrative: 13 km to Jamili PA, Turkey
Less than 6 km to Machakhela NP

After the transfer of land/forest to the Machakhela National Park administration from the Forestry Agency of Achara Autonomous Republic in Autumn 2014, the territory is being managed as the protected area and thus the distance between the Mtirala/Kintrishi PA complex and the nearest forest habitat PA (i.e. Machakhela NP) is less than 6km. The national boundary of Georgia and Turkey forms the southern boundary of the Machakhela NP. The Jamilil Biosphere Reserve lies also along the border and thus the 3rd zone (Transition zone) is contiguous with Machakhela NP. The Machakhela National Park admisnitration has accepted the legal ownership/management of the for

description.narrative: Necessary infrastructure investment is made by APA and Achara authorities to establish effective management of the NP

comment.narrative: Zero
Approx. 120,000 USD

Both the Agency for Protected Areas and the local municipality have already committed significant resources to the establishment of the NP. This includes baseline inputs such as staff, basic as well as additional equipment (additional used vehicle from APA) and, as agreed during PPG stage, the refurbishment of 4km of the Machakhela valley road by the municipality has been completed during 2014-2015 (project cost around 404,000 US$).

description.narrative: Machakhela NP boundaries and zonation decided and participatory management plan in existence

comment.narrative: Boundaries only provisionally demarcated and zonation not carried out

Clearly defined and consensually agreed boundaries and zones by yr 2
Consensually agreed Management plan exists by yr 3

The project is well on track to meet the target, expected date September 2015: A contract to undertake the detailed demarcation and land classification of the NP was selected in April 2015 by the project in agreement with APA. The PA boundary demarcation is ongoing including the collection and inputting all existing cartographic, land and field surveys data into GIS. The contractor closely liaises and informs local government and communities on the progress during implementation of this task. This activity is expected to be completed in September 2015. Additionally, a contractor has been selected to undertake a detailed resource inventory of the NP and surrounding area (baseline studies of biodiversity, traditional use, cultural heritage, etc.), which will form the baseline for monitoring, development of a zoning plan as well as the initial NP management plan (scheduled for 2016). The contractor should start its work in August 2015 and complete by February 2016.

description.narrative: Level of involvement of communities in the management and governance of the NP

comment.narrative: N/A

Public-Civil Society-Community PA Planning and Management Governance Board established with proper representation and involvement of local communities in the planning and management of the Machakhela NP (by year 2)

The Project Coordination Group established and operating that includes local government and community representatives. The primary role of this group is to ensure coordination and information sharing during the next 2 years of intense activities to establish the functional capacity of the NP (i.e boundary and zoning, NP Administration training, infrastructure and equipment, management plan development, etc). Its secondary important role includes the creation of a mechanism by which the NP and local stakeholders can constructively interact. A study of existing and potential mechanisms for maximising practical and meaningful interaction and collaboration between communities living within the borderline of the NP (or "support zone") and the protected area is to be commissioned in the 2nd half of 2015. The study will guide the project on most viable and feasible structures and mechanisms for ensuring community engagement and role in NP management that will be incorporated into the management planning process in 2016.

description.narrative: Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC
Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC.
Biennial Update Report (BUR) completed and submitted to UNFCCC (Y/N). GHG emissions inventory report for 2010-2011 is updated and for 2012-2013 is completed.

comment.narrative: Georgia pledged to submit its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) to the UNFCCC by 2016; National Circumstance Chapter of SNC covers situation until 2012; Georgia’s GHG inventory submitted to the UNFCCC covers years until 2012; Mitigation strategy is currently being prepared under the TNC; UNEP TNA was completed in September 2012. Georgia’s First Biennial Update Report will build on the findings and recommendations of Third National Communication, as well as the outcomes of the ongoing complementary projects in the country, and will be submitted to the UNFCCC in 2016.

description.narrative: Agricultural Development and Livelihoods Enhancement in Abkhazia
Project aims at enhancing livelihood security and employment opportunities of returnees and communities across Abkhazia through market based agricultural development initiatives.

Indicator 1.2.1: Number of established laboratories. Indicator 1.2.2: Number of personnel trained in application of new techniques. Indicator 1.2.3: Number of extension personal/lead farmers trained, number of women Indicator 1.2.4: Number of farmers utilizing soil analysis. Indicator 1.2.5: Number of fertilization tests undertaken. Indicator 1.1.1: Number of employment and income-generation opportunities created Indicator 1.1.2: Number of value chain assessments carried out with in agricultural sectors with high potential for employment creation Indicator 1.1.3: Number of districts assessed on existing agriculture extension capabilities. Indicator 2.1.1: Number of men and women benefitting from improved, diversified livelihoods opportunities Indicator 2.1.2: Number of men and women who benefit from improved market access to sell agricultural produce Indicator 2.1.3: Number of greenhouse producers supported Indicator 2.1.4: Number of productivity workshops conducted. Indicator 2.1.5: Number of surveys to assess situation in the sector. Indicator 2.2.1: Increased product diversity at higher prices. Indicator 3.1.1: Enhanced access to strengthened or new production input supply alternatives. Indicator 3.1.2: Plans are in place to improve farmers access to inputs through revolving funds or other means for input supply financing. Indicator 3.2.1: Number of successful pilot farmers markets outside current market areas.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1 Absence of a coordinated, well-trained, widely accessible extension system capable of providing the knowledge required by farmers to improve profitability and compete in today’s markets. Baseline 1.2: Absence of a widely accessible, affordable system for soil testing, analysis, and effective fertilization recommendations based on this analysis. Baseline 2.1: Limited volumes and diversity of greenhouse production by small-to-medium sized farmers with productivity challenges. Baseline 2.2: Primarily local marketing of limited diversity of greenhouse products at higher prices. Baseline 3.1: Farmers do not have necessary access to appropriate types and quality of production inputs that are reasonably priced and for which financing can be secured, nor access to markets which can handle greater output volumes or higher farmer prices. Baseline 3.2: Farmers are generally constrained to selling their products locally at prices below those which might be secured in other markets

1.1.1/ 300 displaced men and women (of which at least 20 % women)) and host community members who benefit from improved income generating activities 1.1.2/ A minimum of 20 local extension personnel provided trainings, bringing together specialists from both Eastern and Western Abkhazia.. 1.1.3/ A minimum of 500 farmers benefited from improved extension services.
1.2.1/ A minimum of 10 additional local extension personnel/lead farmers trained in proper collection of soil samples and provision of advice, bringing together specialists and farmers from both Eastern and Western Abkhazia in joint sessions. (at least 10 % women) 1.2.2/ A minimum of 200 farmers utilized soil analysis and resulting recommendations. 1.2.3/ A minimum of 4 fertilization test/demonstration plots undertaken.
2.1.1/ 25 of men and women benefitting from improved, diversified livelihoods opportunities (at least 20 % women) 2.1.2/ 25 of men and women who benefit from improved market access to sell agricultural produce (at least 20 % women) 2.1.3/ A minimum of 4 new greenhouses established and 2 greenhouses serving as models/demonstration (UNHCR indicator: 2 small business associations formed/supported in Eastern Abkhazia) 2.1.4/ A minimum of 2 joint productivity workshops conducted for beneficiaries across communities from Western and Eastern Abkhazia. 2.1.5/ A minimum of 1 greenhouse association established.
2.2.1 – 2.2.2 A greenhouse marketing strategy developed and a minimum of 1 greenhouse associations addressing identified challenges.
3.1.1/ A minimum of 1 input supply entity established or strengthened Target 2015: 3.2.1/A minimum of 1 pilot farmers’ market organized in Sukhum/i for agricultural producers from all targeted districts and/or other intervention points in food distribution system identified.

description.narrative: Land border management between Georgia and Azerbaijan

The overall objective of the project is to improve operational capacities of the border agencies of Azerbaijan and Georgia by ensuring coordinated operations at land border with eventual positive impact on overall security in the region and whole Europe.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Intergovernmental Agreement on border delegates between Georgia and Azerbaijan enforced and operationalised.
2 a. EU Best Practices of border guarding and border surveillance presented to senior operational staff 2.b. Coordinated patrolling by Georgian and Azeri border guards conducted on a regular basis. 2.c. At least 50 senior and operational staff actively participating at the national and bilateral thematic workshops 2.d.Positive feedback of staff on professional skills development training 2.e. Training programs for the border guard agencies of two countries are in place and use
3. New Sector offices built and provided to the project area sectors;Specialised equipment is installed and operational; Border staff trained in the use and maintenance of the new equipment.

comment.narrative: Border Cooperation agreement between Georgia and Azerbaijan is in place. However, the international agreement on border delegates between two countries should be endorsed and additional protocols on cooperation updated. There is also a problem of poor infrastructure on Georgian side of the border, lack of adequate equipment as well as lack of coordinated patrolling along the land border .

1.Basic Training Program for Border Guards updated and endorsed and 15 senior officials of border operating agencies have been trained. 2. List of needed subjects for training identified and prepared 3. More than 20 border officials trained on land border surveillance so far. 4. Construction of two sector office buildings commenced

description.narrative: Green Cities: Integrated Sustainable Transport for the City of Batumi and the Adjara Region

Promote sustainable transport in Batumi and Achara by: development of urban transport plans;development of studies and functional plans for low carbon transport;investments in sustainable transport measures;development of sustainable transport plans.
Energy - power generation
Harmonization of information management for improved knowledge and monitoring of the global environment in Georgia

title.narrative: Harmonization of information management for improved knowledge and monitoring of the global environment in Georgia

description.narrative: Best practices and innovative approaches, for meeting the Rio Conventions, development of capacities in Ministry of Environment and the Environmental Information and Education Centre for improved environmental management
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Continue advocacy/promotion of DRR in Georgia in continuation of phase 1 and 2 of DRR projects and CADRI Supported Capacity Assessment findings

Strengthening of the national DRR capacities by (1) provision of technical support to staff involved in national and sectorial planning and (2) strengthening disaster preparedness for effective response based on the recommendations by the CADRI mission.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Guidelines for effective mainstreaming of DRR developed 2. DRR mainstreamed in at least 2 local/regional development plans 3. Unified multi-hazard risk assessment methodology developed 4. Training programme on multi-hazard risk assessment for training of trainers 5. Unified methodology on post disaster methodology on post disaster damage and recovery needs assessment developed Support in organizing at least 5 coordination meetings Support OCHA in organizing at least 3 Inter-agency contingency planning simulation exercises National Emergency Management Information System (NEMIS) introduced ensuring international standards for data collection, storage and sharing for effective response to emergencies A comprehensive assessment of a multi-hazard early warning system conducted Recommendations/action plan for strengthening a multi-hazard early warning system for short term warning provided

comment.narrative: 1. Recommendations/action plan for strengthening national multi-hazard early warning system developed (indicator 1) 2. A comprehensive multi-hazard early warning system assessment conducted (indicator 3) 3. Unified multi-hazard risk assessment methodology developed (Indicator 3) 4. Post disaster damage/recovery needs assessment methodology developed (indicator 5 ) 5. Development of National Emergency Management Information Management System initiated (indicator 5)

description.narrative: Strengthen national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and build capacity towards implementation of future provisions.

Undertake a Mercury Initial Assessment to enable the GoG to determine the needs for ratification of the Minamata Convention and establish a national foundation to undertake future work towards the implementation of the Convention.

description.narrative: UN JP on Human Rights

Overall objective of the Joint Programme (JP) is to enhance capacities of government institutions and Parliamentary Committees on Rights and Civil Integration and Legal Issues and improve mechanisms for better protection of human rights in Georgia.
Human rights affairs

policy, planning and administration
Tbilisi Floods-Post-Disaster needs assessment and risk-informed recovery

Tbilisi was hit by a major flash flood that wrought significant damage and caused loss of life through a large swath in the middle of the city. It was decided to assist the GoG in rapid post-disaster needs assessment for short and medium term recovery.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
1. Recovery needs assessment report produced 2. Recovery framework developed

comment.narrative: Insufficient government capacities to conduct long-term recovery needs assessment and develop recovery framework Lack and/or insufficient hazard data for Tbilisi Lack of updated hydrological and geological hazard risk mapping of the city Limitations in coordination between donor community and the Government on implementation of the short-to medium term recovery efforts; inaccurate/ limited information of various datasets, cases of duplication of efforts; Government request to assist with the coordination
1. Post-disaster Recovery needs assessment conducted 2. Recovery framework and plans developed

title.narrative: UN JP on Access to Justice

description.narrative: Overall objective of the project is to enhance capacities of government institutions to promote access to justice for all and qualitative, coherent and child-friendly justice system for children in Georgia.
Human rights affairs
